name: Garuda
abilities: Divine Flight: Unlimited speed and mobility in all realms
Strength: Capable of carrying mountains and gods
Serpent Dominion: Can perceive and combat serpent creatures
Vitality Transfer: Can grant or restore vital energy
Multi-realm Travel: Can traverse physical and spiritual worlds
weaknesses: Devotion: Bound by loyalty to Vishnu
Serpent Curse: Ancient enmity with nagas makes those encounters volatile
Dharmic Restriction: Cannot act against cosmic order
habitat: Heavens, sacred mountains, temples dedicated to Vishnu
behavior: Noble and righteous, devoted to Vishnu, protector of dharma (cosmic order)

christian.overview: Garuda, the divine eagle-mount of Vishnu, presents parallels with biblical cherubim and the eagle symbolism of Christian tradition. As a serpent-devouring eagle serving the supreme deity, Garuda invites comparison with Christ's victory over the serpent.

biblicalParallels.description: The woman given "two wings of a great eagle" to escape the dragon parallels Garuda's role in opposing serpentine forces.
The eagle face of the cherubim parallel Garuda's role as a divine vehicle and throne-bearer.
The enmity between the woman's seed and the serpent finds a striking parallel in Garuda's eternal conflict with the Nagas.
Those who wait on the Lord rising on eagle's wings parallels Garuda carrying devotees to divine presence.

patristicInterpretation.summary: While Church Fathers did not directly address Garuda, their understanding of eagle symbolism and divine thrones provides interpretive parallels.

sources.author: Early Christian missionaries to India
sources.interpretation: Some early Christian interpreters in India saw in Garuda a distorted memory of cherubic beings, noting the eagle imagery and throne-bearing function.

comparativeTheology.vishnu_garuda: Garuda serving Vishnu as vahana (vehicle) parallels the cherubim bearing God's throne-chariot in Ezekiel - both represent supreme deities borne by winged beings.
comparativeTheology.serpentEnmity: Garuda's role as serpent-devourer parallels the Genesis curse placing enmity between the serpent and humanity, fulfilled in Christ crushing the serpent's head.
comparativeTheology.divineMission: Garuda carrying Vishnu on salvific missions parallels the Holy Spirit (often represented as a dove/bird) bearing Christ to his ministry.

christian.typologicalReading: Garuda's victory over serpents and his restoration of amrita (immortality nectar) to the gods provides a parallel narrative to Christ's victory over the serpent Satan and his restoration of eternal life to humanity.
scholarlyReferences: Doniger, Wendy. The Hindus: An Alternative History. New York: Penguin, 2009.
